A '''brochure''' is an informative paper document (often also used for advertising) that can be folded into a template, [[pamphlet]] or [[Folded leaflet|leaflet]]. A brochure can also be a set of related unfolded papers put into a pocket folder or packet. Brochurest are promotional documents, primarily used to introduce a [[company]], [[organization]], [[Product (business)|products]] or [[Service (economics)|services]] and inform prospective customers or members of the public of the benefits.
Brochures are distributed in many different ways: as newspaper inserts, handed out personally, by mail or placed in brochure racks in high traffic locations especially in tourist precincts. They may be considered as [[grey literature]]. <ref name="UysalFesenmaier2012">{{cite book|author1=Muzaffer Uysal|author2=Daniel Fesenmaier|title=Communication and Channel Systems in Tourism Marketing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jtTYXLB71wkC&pg=PA112|date=12 November 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-58697-2|pages=11 2}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:Arizona Limited brochure 1940.jpg|thumb|A 1940s brochure advertising the train, Arizona Limited]] A brochure is usually folded and only includes summary information that is promotional in character. A booklet is usually several sheets of paper with a cardstock cover and bound with staples, string or plastic binding. In contrast, a single piece of unfolded paper is usually called an insert, [[Flyer_(pamphlet)|flyer]] or bulletin.
==Varieties== [[File:Folding.svg|thumb|1: letter/C tri-fold, 2: gate tri-fold, 3: roll/double gate fold, 4: accordion z-fold, 5: double (parallel) fold, 6: double right-angle / French fold]] Brochures available in electronic format are called ''e-brochures''. This format has the added benefit of unlimited distribution and cost savings when compared to traditional paper brochures.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ebrochuresforeveryone.co.uk/ebrochures/ebrochure-benefits.php|title=eBrochure benefits - eBrochures For Everyone (Page Turning Catalogues and Brochures)|last=Everyone|first=Webs For|website=www.ebrochuresforeveryone.co.uk|access-date=2017-01-16}}</ref>
The most common types of single-sheet brochures are the ''bi-fold'' (a single sheet printed on both sides and folded into halves) and the ''tri-fold'' (the same, but folded into thirds). A bi-fold brochure results in four panels (two panels on each side), while a tri-fold results in six panels (three panels on each side).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.brochuredesignservice.com/Brochures.aspx|title=Types of Brochures - Brochure Types|website=www.brochuredesignservice.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref>
Other [http://www.renaissancebrochure.com/content/deciding-brochure-design-structure-binding-and-folding brochure fold arrangements] are possible: the accordion or "z-fold" method, the "c-fold" method, etc. Larger sheets, such as those with detailed maps or expansive photo spreads, are folded into four, five, or six panels. When two card fascia are affixed to the outer panels of the z-folded brochure.
Booklet brochures are made of multiple sheets most often [[saddle-stitch]]ed, stapled on the creased edge, or [[perfect bound]] like a [[Paperback|paperback book]], and result in eight or more panels.
==Editing and design== Brochures and leaflets are carefully edited to promote an organization or business, to sell a service or product, raise awareness or to champion a cause. Editors will be clear who they are trying to reach and define their target audience. They will also be conscious of skillful layout and design aimed at attracting the attention of their readers.<ref name="Spencer-Thomas 2010">{{Cite web | title = Designing Leaflets and Brochures | last = Spencer-Thomas | first = Owen | work = [[Owen Spencer-Thomas]] | date = 2018 | accessdate = 2018-02-13 | url = http://www.owenspencer-thomas.com/journalism/media-tips/designing-a-leaflet/ | quote = }}</ref>
==Printing== Brochures are often printed using [[four-color process]] on thick, glossy paper to give an impression of quality. Businesses may print small quantities of brochures on a [[computer printer]] or on a [[Digital printing|digital printer]], but [[offset printing]] turns out higher quantities at a lower cost per unit.
Compared with a flyer, a brochure usually uses [[Paper density|higher-quality paper]], more color, and is folded.
==See also== {{Portal|Literature}} * [[Propaganda]] *[[Marketing brochure|Marketing Brochure]]

'''Dillard Eugene Bird''' (October 8, 1906 – January 2, 1990)<ref>[http://sortedbyname.com/pages/b151667.html sortedbyname], accessed 2017-09-27.</ref> was an American [[industrial engineer|industrial]] and [[consulting engineer]], founder and President of Dillard E. Bird Associates, consultants to management in [[Cincinnati]], Ohio.<ref>''Modern Machine Shop,'' Volume 20. 1947. p. 246</ref> He was known as "veteran in the field of personnel administration,"<ref>''The Cincinnati Enquirer,'' from Cincinnati, Ohio. January 14, 1946. p. 15.</ref> and as the 10th president of the [[Society for Advancement of Management]] from 1949 to 1951.<ref>[[Society for Advancement of Management]], ''Proceedings : Society for Advancement of Management. Conference,'' 1949. p. 2.</ref>
== Biography == === Youth, education and early career === Bird was born in 1906 in [[Covington, Kentucky]], son of Nora M. Bird (1874-1963).<ref>[https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=Bird&GSiman=1&GScnty=1047&GRid=155712225& Dillard Eugene Bird, Sr] at findagrave.com. Accessed 2017-09-28</ref> He had obtained his AB from the [[University of Cincinnati]] in 1933 under [[Ralph C. Davis]],<ref name="OSU 1937">Ohio State University. ''Abstracts of Master's Theses.'' Nr. 26-30. 1937. p. 24</ref> and his MBA from the [[Ohio State University]] in 1938.<ref>Ohio State University. ''Annual Report.'' 1939. p. 116</ref> In 1951 he also obtained his PhD at Ohio State with the thesis, entitled ''The relation of stabilization within the business organization to guarantee of work or wages.''<ref>''The American economic review,'' Volume 41. 1951. p. 823</ref>
After his graduation Bird had joined the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]] faculty, where he was placement officer in 1937<ref name="Pennsylvania, 1937. p. 32">University Placement Service of the University of Pennsylvania, ''University Placement Review,'' Volumes 9-12. 1937. p. 32</ref> and Assistant Director of Student Personnel by 1939.<ref>University of Pennsylvania. ''Directory of Officers, Faculty, Students, Departments.'' 1939. p. 15</ref> He also taught industrial management and industrial relations at [[Wharton School of Finance and Commerce]], and was industry and government consultant in human relations.<ref name="USO 1947">United States. Office of the US High Commissioner for Germany. Office of Labor Affairs. ''Visiting Expert Series.'' Nr. 1-15, 1947. p. 127</ref>
=== Further career and other work === Around 1943 Bird founded his own firm, Dillard E. Bird Associates, consultants to management in Cincinnati, Ohio.<ref name="USO 1947"/> Among others he was expert for the United States Office of the US High Commissioner for Germany in 1937,<ref name="Pennsylvania, 1937. p. 32"/> the National Wholesale Druggists' Association in 1949,<ref>National Wholesale Druggists' Association (1949). ''N.W.D.A. Year Book.'' p. 110</ref> and the SEE Foremanship Foundation in [[Dayton, Ohio]] in 1951.
One of his notable employees was the Carl Hartley Elliott, who was junior management consultant in 1947-48, and later professor and president of the [[Trine University]]. Since 1942 Bird also taught personnel administration and labor relations at the evening college of the [[University of Cincinnati]].<ref name="USO 1947"/>
Bird was the 10th president of the [[Society for Advancement of Management]] from 1949 to 1951. He was the successor of [[Charles C. James]], and was succeeded by [[Leon J. Dunn]].<ref>''S.A.M. Advanced Management Journal,'' Volume 53, 1988. p. 40</ref>
=== Family === Dillard Eugene Bird married Mary Carmichael Andrews, daughter of James H. M. Andrews and Esther McKinley (Bender) Andrews.<ref>''The National Cyclopaedia of American Biography,'' 1967. p. 367</ref> They had a son, Dillard Eugene Bird, Jr. (1941-2015).
== Selected publications == * Dillard Eugene Bird. ''Foremanship Training, Development, Methods: A Case Study.'' Master thesis University of Cincinnati, 1933.<ref name="OSU 1937"/> * Bird, Dillard Eugene. ''Building human relations.'' Cincinnati, 1948<ref>U.S. Government Printing Office, ''Catalog of Copyright Entries. Third Series: 1948,'' 1948. p. 353</ref> * Dillard E. Bird. ''The Development of Management Associations in Germany.'' 1949. * Dillard E. Bird. ''The relation of stabilization within the business organization to guarantee of work or wages.'' PhD thesis at Ohio State, 1951. * Dillard Eugene Bird. ''The Guarantee of Work and Wages.'' Ohio State University, 1953. (614 pp.)
;Articles, a selection * Bird, Dillard E. ''Chapter operations manual.'' SEE Society for the Advancement of Management, 1948.<ref>U.S. Government Printing Office, ''Books and Pamphlets, Including Serials and Contributions to Periodicals, Volume 3,'' 1949. p. 20.</ref> * Bird, Dillard E. ''Dillard E. Bird Associates, consultants to management.'' 1948.<ref>U.S. Government Printing Office, ''Catalog of Copyright Entries. Third Series: 1948,'' 1949. p. 33</ref> * Bird, Dillard E. ''Survey of economic education.'' SEE Foremanship Foundation, Dayton, Ohio, 1951.<ref>U.S. Government Printing Office, ''Catalog of Copyright Entries. Third Series: 1951,'' 1952. p. 421</ref>

Donald Cameron}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox person |name= Don Cameron |birth_date = 1939 |birth_place=[[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] |death_place= |image= Heineken double decker balloon in the 70s.jpg |caption= Don Cameron in the 1970s (Top Right) }}
'''Don Cameron MBE''' BSc MA MIEE D.Eng [[Royal Scottish Geographical Society|FRSGS]] (born 1939) is a [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[hot air balloon|balloonist]], and later founder of [[Cameron Balloons]], the world's largest hot air balloon manufacturer.
==Early life and career==
Born in [[Glasgow]] in 1939, Cameron went to [[Allan Glen's School]]<ref>http://www.cameronballoons.co.uk/faq/historyofcameronballoons</ref> and then went on to study [[aeronautical engineering]] at the [[University of Glasgow]], graduating in 1961. In 1963 he obtained a master's degree at [[Cornell University|Cornell]], [[United States]]. He then joined the [[Bristol Aeroplane Company]]. Cameron developed Britain's first modern [[hot air balloon]] entitled ''[[Bristol Belle]]'' which flew for the first time at [[Weston on the Green]] in [[Oxfordshire]], [[England]] on 9 July 1967. In 1968 Cameron and Leslie Goldsmith founded Omega Balloons which constructed ten balloons, before the company split into [[Cameron Balloons]] and Western Balloons in 1970.
[[Cameron Balloons]] of [[Bristol]], England, was formed by Cameron in 1971 - five years after he constructed his first balloon. The new company was based in [[Cotham, Bristol]] where a total of twenty nine balloons were made in the basement of the property. 1971 also saw Cameron build ''Golden Eagle'', a balloon designed specifically to fly across the [[Sahara]] to shoot a film for [[Jack Le Vien]].
In 1978 his attempt to make the premier [[Atlantic]] crossing by balloon ended when bad weather forced his heated [[helium]] balloon ''Zanussi'' down after a 2,000 mile flight from Canada. It was piloted by Cameron and Christopher Davey. They left [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador]] on 26 July 1978, covered 1,780 miles, and ditched on 30 July 1978 in the [[Bay of Biscay]] only 110 miles from [[France]] after a tear developed in the balloon. The two planned a second attempt, but discarded their plans when the ''[[Double Eagle II]]'' successfully made a [[transatlantic flight]] three weeks later. Cameron and Davey were awarded the Gold Medal of the [http://royalaeroclub.co.uk/medals-and-awards.php?title=&id=54 Royal Aero Club] in the same year.
Never averse to technical challenges, Cameron went on to write computer programmes to design specially shaped balloons.
Cameron has received the gold, silver and bronze medals of the British [[Royal Aero Club]] for his ballooning achievements which include being the first man to cross the [[Sahara]] and the [[Alps]] by hot-air balloon, and making the first flight between the UK and the former USSR in 1990.
His dream came true in 1992 when he flew a balloon of his own design from [[Bangor, Maine]], [[United States|U.S.]] to [[Portugal]] and took second place in the first ever [[transatlantic balloon race]].
In 1999, [[Breitling Orbiter]] 3, built by [[Cameron Balloons]], made the first non-stop flight round the world.
Don Cameron is one of the few [[aeronauts]] to be awarded the [[Harmon Trophy]], as the 'World's Outstanding Aviator' in 1999

{{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} '''Dr. Donald McGillivray Elder''' is a New Zealand engineer and businessman. He was the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of the New Zealand mining and energy company [[Solid Energy]].
== Biography == Don Elder was born in [[Christchurch]], New Zealand. He attended [[high school]] at [[Christ's College, Christchurch|Christ's College]] and graduated from the [[University of Canterbury]] with a degree in engineering. He then gained a [[Rhodes Scholarship]],<ref>[http://www.library.otago.ac.nz/exhibitions/rhodes_scholars/pdf/rhodes_scholars.pdf New Zealand Rhodes Scholars] (PDF)</ref> to go to [[Oxford University]]. Later, he moved back to New Zealand and became CEO of Solid Energy.
Elder resigned as CEO of Solid Energy on 4 February 2013, having served as the CEO for 12 years since May 2000.<ref>http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/elder-resigns-solid-energy-ch-135347</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/8700745/Don-Elders-grandiose-Solid-Energy-plans |title= Don Elder's grandiose Solid Energy plans |publisher= Stuff (Fairfax) |date=22 May 2015}}</ref>
Elder currently lives in Christchurch, New Zealand. <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/8411392/Ex-Solid-Energy-boss-asks-media-to-leave |title= Ex-Solid Energy boss asks media to leave |publisher= Stuff (Fairfax) |date= 12 March 2013}}</ref>

'''Downtown St. John's''' is the historic core and [[central business district]] of [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]], [[Canada]]. Located north of St. John's harbour, it is the business, entertainment, and tourism centre with office buildings, hotels, restaurants, and other services.
==Geography== [[File:Basilica st.johns2.jpg|thumb|left|View of Downtown St. John's from the harbour. The downtown is bounded by St. John's Harbour to the east.]] The historic boundaries of downtown St. John's is usually thought to start at the harbour, extend north to Duckworth Street, and is bounded by Patrick Street in the west and Empire Avenue in the east. In recent years, the boundaries of downtown have extended further north. As such, it usually takes in Military Road and LeMarchant Road or as far Merrymeeting Road.<ref>{{cite web|title=City of St. John’s: Downtown Strategy for Economic Development and Heritage |url=http://www.stjohns.ca/cityservices/planning/pdfs/Downtown%20Strategy%20Final%20Report.pdf|publisher=City of St. John's|accessdate=4 March 2012|page=1.2|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016210219/http://www.stjohns.ca/cityservices/planning/pdfs/Downtown%20Strategy%20Final%20Report.pdf|archivedate=16 October 2007|df=}}</ref>
==Culture== Downtown St. John's is home to [[The Rooms]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador]]'s cultural facility, which unites the Provincial Museum, the Provincial Art Gallery and the Provincial Archives all under one roof.<ref>[http://www.therooms.ca/ The Rooms]. Therooms.ca. Retrieved on 2010-11-26.</ref> The A1C postal code in the downtown area is known to have one of the highest concentrations of artists in Canada. <ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/travel/the-rocks-capital-is-rockin-again/article1698724/ The Rock's capital is rockin' again]</ref> [[File:The Rooms (North face), St. John's, Newfoundland, Canada.jpg|thumb|Situated in Downtown St. John's, [[The Rooms]] is home to the provincial archives, art gallery, and museum.]] ===Entertainment=== The [[Mile One Centre]] is located in downtown St. John's. It is the main sports and entertainment centre in the city and one of the finest entertainment centres in Canada. Built in 2001, it has been the home of the St. John's Maple Leafs, St. John's Fog Devils, and currently, the [[St. John's IceCaps]]. It also plays host to many of the concerts that visit the city. In April 2010 Mile One as well as George Street hosted the [[Juno Awards]] for the second time.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2009/01/22/juno-stjohns.html 2010 Junos set for St. John's. [[CBC News]] January 22, 2010]</ref>
The Downtown Busker Festival is an annual event held in August. The festival is the only one of its kind in the province and features local talent as well as national and international performers.<ref>[http://www.downtownstjohns.com/busker/ busker busker – Downtown St. John's, Newfoundland, Canada] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100912052929/http://www.downtownstjohns.com/busker/ |date=September 12, 2010 }}. Downtownstjohns.com. Retrieved on 2010-11-26.</ref>
====Nightlife==== [[File:George Street St John Newfoundland (41364917921).jpg|thumb|[[George Street (St. John's)|George Street]] is a small road located in downtown and is the focal point of the city's nightlife.]] [[George Street, St. John's|George Street]] is located downtown and is the focal point of the city's nightlife. The short street is populated mainly by bars and pubs, which are open later than most others in [[Canada]].
The street is the venue for an annual [[Mardi Gras]] celebration in October. However, the largest celebration on George Street is the six-night George Street Festival. The festival occurs at the end of July or early August and typically concludes on the Tuesday night before the [[Royal St. John's Regatta]], which is set for the first Wednesday in August. Over 120,000 people making their way through the streets during the six-day period.
=== Historic buildings === St. John's is the oldest city in [[North America]],{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} which has meant that many buildings throughout the city, specifically in the downtown core, have been designated by either the [[Historic Sites and Monuments Board of Canada]] or the [[Heritage Foundation of Newfoundland and Labrador]] as Historic Places.<ref>[http://www.heritagefoundation.ca/home.aspx Heritage Foundation of Newfoundland and Labrador]. Heritagefoundation.ca. Retrieved on 2010-11-26.</ref>
==Economy== [[File:TD Place.jpg|thumb|upright|TD Place in Downtown St. John's. All [[Big Five banks|Big Five Canadian banks]] have operations in St. John's downtown core.]] Downtown St. John's is the central business district for the city and is the centre of the oil and gas industry in [[Eastern Canada]]. [[ExxonMobil]] [[Canada]] has its headquarters in the Cabot Building on New Gower Street, as well [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]], [[Statoil]] and [[Suncor Energy]] along with other oil and gas companies have major operations downtown.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2010/07/21/nl-exxonmobile-relocting-721.html ExxonMobil Canada moving to St. John's]</ref><ref>[http://www.suncor.com/en/independent/320.aspx Suncor Energy Contacts]</ref> [[Fortis Inc.]] have their headquarters in the [[Fortis Building]] on Water Street and they own and operate several of the office buildings and hotels downtown.<ref>[http://www.fortisproperties.com/en/home/aboutus/propertyportfolio.aspx Fortis Properties – Property Profile]</ref> All of the [[Big Five banks|Big Five Canadian banks]] have operations in the downtown core as well.
===Hotels=== Many of the hotels located in the city of St. John's are located in the downtown area, with many major hotel chains as well as local establishments maintaining a location there.
====List of hotels==== *City Hostel *[[Courtyard by Marriott|Courtyard by Marriott St. John's]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Courtyard St. John's Newfoundland|url=http://www.marriott.com/hotels/travel/yytcy-courtyard-st-johns-newfoundland/|publisher=Marriott|accessdate=24 July 2011}}</ref> *[[Delta Hotels|Delta St. John's Hotel]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Delta St. John's Hotel and Conference Centre|url=http://www.deltahotels.com/hotels/hotels.php?hotelId=7/|publisher=Delta Hotels and Resorts|accessdate=24 July 2011}}</ref> *Duckworth B&B *Ryan Mansion<ref>[http://www.ryanmansion.com/about.php Ryan Mansion]</ref> *Quality Hotel – Harbourview<ref>[http://www.choicehotels.ca/hotels/hotel?hotel=CN246|accessdate=2009-09-19 Hotels, Rooms, Reservations – Choice Hotels Canada]. Choicehotels.ca. Retrieved on 2010-11-26.</ref> *[[Hotel Newfoundland|Sheraton Hotel Newfoundland]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Sheraton Hotel Newfoundland|url=http://www.starwoodhotels.com/sheraton/property/overview/index.html?propertyID=3455|publisher=Sheraton Hotels and Resorts|accessdate=24 July 2011}}</ref> *Spa At The Monastery And Suites
===Retail=== Downtown features some of the finest shopping in the city available with fashionable clothing boutiques for men and women, and unique specialty stores. Art galleries, bookstores and music stores featuring the work of local artists are scattered throughout the downtown area.<ref>[http://downtownstjohns.com/shop/shopping/ Shopping - Downtown St. John's]</ref>
==Government== [[File:Johncabotplace2.jpg|thumb|upright|Departments and agencies of the [[Government of Canada]] maintain offices in several buildings in the downtown core, such as the John Cabot Building.]] === Municipal === Downtown St. John's is the home of the [[St. John's City Council|St. John's City Council Chamber]] at city hall. Offices for the mayor, city councillors, and additional staff are also located in city hall.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stjohns.ca/cityhall/index.jsp |title=The City of St.John's - City Hall |publisher=Stjohns.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221001458/http://www.stjohns.ca/cityhall/index.jsp |archivedate=2008-12-21 |df= }}</ref>
===Federal=== The [[Newfoundland and Labrador]] office for the regional federal minister is located downtown, as well many [[Government of Canada|Federal Government]] departments and agencies are also located downtown in different buildings including: the Sir Humphrey Gilbert Building and the John Cabot Building.
==Demographic== There are 10,025 people living in the downtown area. 52.5% are less than 35 years of age. 36.6% are between the ages of 36–64 and 10.4% are over the age of 64. The average age is 35.9 years and there are 4060 private households.
==See also== {{portal|St. John's}} *[[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]] *[[Newfoundland and Labrador]]

{{No footnotes|date= October 2014}} '''Efficient Consumer Response''' ('''ECR''') is a joint trade and industry body working towards making the grocery sector as a whole more responsive to consumer demand and promote the removal of unnecessary costs from the supply chain.<!--But WHERE? What status? Further down, there's a European version ...-->
There are four focus areas under ECR: [[demand management]], [[supply management (procurement)|supply management]], enablers and integrators, which are intended to be addressed as an integrated set. These form the basis of the ECR Global Scorecard.
==ECR Community== In September 2016, ECR Community replaced ECR Europe as the focal point for consumer goods retailers and manufacturers to work together for the benefit of consumers across Europe. Owned and managed by the ECR National Associations, which span Europe and the international ECR Shrink and On Shelf Availability group. These associations are supported by over 1,800 retailers, manufacturers and service providers.
==ECR Europe== ECR Europe was launched in 1994. With its headquarters in Brussels, the organization works in co-operation with national ECR initiatives in most European countries. Participation in projects at European and national levels is open to companies in the grocery and [[Fast-Moving Consumer Goods]] sectors – including retailers, wholesalers, manufacturers, suppliers, brokers and third-party service providers such as logistics operators.
Every year ECR Europe organizes projects where companies from Europe explore new areas of working together. The results of these projects are published and there is an annual ECR Europe conference.

Europe and Asia Pacific)] * [http://www.globalscorecard.net/ ECR Global Scorecard] * [http://www.wirtschaftslexikon24.net/d/efficient-consumer-response/efficient-consumer-response.htm Scientific Essay about Efficient Consumer Response in German] (strategies, cooperations)

{{COI|date=September 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Epos Now | logo = Logo Blue on Transparent.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | founded = {{start date|df=yes|2011|}} in [[Norwich]], England | founder = or: | hq_location_city = Norwich, England | hq_location_country = UK | area_served = or: | key_people = Jacyn Heavens (CEO) | industry = Computer Software, Technology | num_employees = | homepage = {{URL|eposnow.com}} | founders = [[Jacyn Heavens]] | areas_served = Global | website = or: }} '''Epos Now''' is a cloud-based software provider, specialising in the design and manufacture of [[electronic point of sale]] (commonly referred to as EPOS), which encompasses features including but not limited to reporting, [[stock control]], and [[Customer relationship management|CRM]] for retail and [[hospitality]] businesses. Epos Now software can be operated from any device or platform with a web-browser or by using Epos Now's [[IOS]] or [[Android (operating system)|Android]] app.
Epos Now's UK headquarters are located in [[Norwich]], England and their US headquarters are in [[Orlando, Florida]].<ref name=EposNowWebsite>{{cite web|title=Epos Now Head Office|url=http://www.eposnow.com/contact-us|website=Epos Now|publisher=Epos Now|accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref> Founded in June 2011, the company was a pioneer in cloud-technology in the EPOS industry and is notable for being the first EPOS company to introduce an AppStore to their customers,<ref name="Norfolk Tech Journal">{{cite web|title=Epos Now's Innovative Work on POS Appstore Recognised With National Retail Award |url=http://www.norfolktechjournal.com/epos-nows-innovative-work-on-pos-appstore-recognised-with-national-retail-award/|work=Norfolk Tech Journal|accessdate=12 January 2016}}</ref> which allows users to customise their system. The Epos Now AppStore was introduced in December 2014. Epos Now's innovation was recognised in 2016, when the company won a [[Queen's Awards for Enterprise|Queen's Award for Enterprise]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/business/royal_approval_four_firms_from_norfolk_and_waveney_honoured_with_queen_s_enterprise_award_1_4503326|title=Royal approval: Four firms from Norfolk and Waveney honoured with Queen’s Enterprise Award|last=Shields|first=Mark|website=Eastern Daily Press|access-date=22 April 2016}}</ref> the UK's highest accolade for business success.
Epos Now is the UK's 13th fastest growing private technology company, and the fastest growing EPOS company in the UK. <ref name="TechTrack">{{cite web|title=Tech Track 100|url=http://www.fasttrack.co.uk/fasttrack/downloads/TechTrack100.pdf|work=The Sunday Times|accessdate=10 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="Insider Media Limited">{{cite web|title=South East and Eastern Firms Feature in Tech Track|url=http://www.insidermedia.com/insider/national/146841-south-east-and-eastern-firms-feature-tech-track/|website=Fast Track|publisher=Insider Media Limited|accessdate= 24 April 2017}}</ref> In 2016 Epos Now was valued in excess of $90 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/jobs/epos_now_chief_is_on_norwich_recruitment_mission_and_has_70_tech_vacancies_1_4430373|title=Epos Now chief is on Norwich 'recruitment mission' and has 70 tech vacancies|website=Eastern Daily Press|access-date=24 April 2017}}</ref>
==History==
Epos Now was founded by [[Jacyn Heavens]] in 2011 with no external investment.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.businessweekly.co.uk/news/hi-tech/17961-norwich-tech-firm-announces-expansion-plans |title=Norwich Tech Firm Announces Expansion Plans |work=Business Weekly |access-date=15 January 2016}}</ref> CEO and founder Jacyn Heavens identified a gap in the market for an affordable EPOS system whilst managing a bar, and after searching for an EPOS system that would be suitable for his business, he started building software that would suit business owners like himself. The Epos Now Appstore was officially launched in September 2015, making it the first Appstore to be released within the EPOS industry.<ref name=AppStoreRelease>{{cite web|title=Epos Now Launches UK's first POS AppStore|url=http://www.retailtechnologyreview.com/articles/2015/09/02/epos-now-launches-uk%E2%80%99s-first-pos-appstore/|website=Retail Technology Review|publisher=Retail Technology Review|accessdate=19 January 2016}}</ref> There are over 20,000 businesses using Epos Now.<ref name=FinancialTimes>{{cite web|last1=Bounds|first1=Andrew|title=Naming Revolution Can Hold Key To Group's Evolution|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/8577f05c-b5ec-11e4-a577-00144feab7de.html|work=Financial Times|accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref>
==Awards== In 2015, Epos Now was awarded 'Epos Innovation of the Year' by Retail Systems,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.retail-systems.com/awards/winners.php |title=Retail Systems Awards 2015 |publisher= Retail Systems |access-date=1 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.norfolktechjournal.com/epos-now-competes-with-the-big-boys-as-norwich-start-up-shortlisted-for-retail-systems-award/|title=Epos Now Competes with the Big Boys |work= Norfolk Tech Journal |access-date= 3 November 2015}}</ref> and was shortlisted for [[Eastern Daily Press|EDP]] Business Awards<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.edpbusinessawards.co.uk/ |title=EDP Business Awards 2015 |publisher= Eastern Daily Press |access-date=19 November 2015}}</ref> and Tech Cities 2015.
In 2016 Epos Now was shortlisted for the UK Cloud Awards in the "Most Innovative SMB Product of the Year" category<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ukcloudawards.co.uk/2016-shortlist|title=2016 Shortlist {{!}} UK Cloud Awards|website=www.ukcloudawards.co.uk|access-date=21 April 2016}}</ref> and the Engagement & Loyalty Awards in the "Most Innovative Technology" category.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.engagementandloyalty.com/shortlist.php|title=Engagement & Loyalty Awards 2016|publisher=engagementandloyalty.com|access-date=21 April 2016}}</ref> Epos Now was also a finalist in 2016 [[The Grocer]] Gold Awards, for the "Technology Supplier of the Year" category.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thegrocergoldawards.co.uk/page/2016_finalists.html|title=2016 Finalists – The Grocer Gold Awards|publisher=thegrocergoldawards.co.uk|access-date=22 April 2016}}</ref>
On 21 April 2016 it was announced the Epos Now had won a [[Queen's Awards for Enterprise|Queen's Award for Enterprise]] in the Innovation category.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/business/royal_approval_four_firms_from_norfolk_and_waveney_honoured_with_queen_s_enterprise_award_1_4503326|title=Royal approval: Four firms from Norfolk and Waveney honoured with Queen’s Enterprise Award|last=Shields|first=Mark|website=Eastern Daily Press|access-date=21 April 2016}}</ref>
Epos Now were named Gold [[Stevie Awards|Stevie Award]] winners for The International Business Awards as "The Most Innovative company of the Year 2016".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stevieawards.com/iba/company-organization-awards-winners-0|title=Company / Organization Awards Winners {{!}} Stevie Awards|publisher=stevieawards.com|access-date=6 September 2016}}</ref>
Epos Now won three [[Eastern Daily Press]] Business Awards in 2016<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.edpbusinessawards.co.uk/winners2016/|title=Winners 2016 {{!}} EDP Business Awards|website=www.edpbusinessawards.co.uk|access-date=23 May 2017}}</ref> in the categories of; Employer of the Year, Tech Innovator of the year and Business of the Year sponsored by [[Barclays]].
The company made the [[Tech Track 100|Tech Track]] 100 three years running, being named the 13th and 32nd and 53rd fastest growing tech company in the UK<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fasttrack.co.uk/league-tables/tech-track-100/league-table/|title=League table – Fast Track|last=TWK|work=Fast Track|access-date=23 May 2017|language=en-GB}}</ref> and named 30th fastest growing company in 2016's [[Deloitte]] Fast 50 with a growth of 597%<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fast50.co.uk/2016-winners/2016-winners.aspx|title=Fast 50 {{!}} 2016 winners|website=www.fast50.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=23 May 2017}}</ref>. Epos Now were named 179th fastest growing tech company in the Deloitte 2016 [[Deloitte Fast 500|Fast 500]] EMEA<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/global/en/pages/technology-media-and-telecommunications/articles/technology-fast-500-emea.html|title=Technology Fast 500™ EMEA Winners {{!}} Deloitte Global {{!}} Technology, Media and Telecommunication|website=Deloitte|language=en|access-date=23 May 2017}}</ref>. Epos Now were named Europes 46th fastest growing company in the [[Financial Times]] 1000 listing<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ig.ft.com/ft-1000/|title=The FT 1000: Europe's fastest-growing companies|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|access-date=23 May 2017}}</ref>.
Epos Now were recognised for their commitment to the professional development of their employees winning a Princess Royal Training Award in 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.princessroyaltrainingawards.com/prta-community-of-excellence/the-awards-2017|title=The Awards 2017 {{!}} Princess Royal Training Awards {{!}} City & Guilds Group|website=www.princessroyaltrainingawards.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-21}}</ref>.
Epos Now were noted as 'Best SaaS Product for small business/SMBs<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cloud-awards.com/2017-saas-shortlist/|title=2017 SaaS Shortlist {{!}} Cloud Computing & SaaS Awards 2016-17|website=www.cloud-awards.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-21}}</ref>' in the 2017 [https://www.cloud-awards.com/software-as-a-service-awards/ SaaS Awards].

'''Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs''' is a European mobility scheme initiated by the [[European Union]] in 2009,<ref>http://www.erasmus-entrepreneurs.eu/</ref> which gives new or aspiring entrepreneurs an opportunity to get a first-hand, practical coaching from experienced entrepreneurs running [[Small and medium-sized enterprises|small and medium-sized businesses]] (SMEs) in one of the 28 [[European Union member states|EU Members States]] or in other countries part of the [https://ec.europa.eu/growth/smes/cosme_en COSME] programme.
The programme helps new and host entrepreneurs to develop relevant skills for managing and expanding their own business.
The duration of the stay abroad can be between one and six months. The European Union provides some financial support to the new entrepreneurs for their stay abroad.
Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs is financed by the [[European Commission]] and operates with the help of intermediary organisations<ref>http://www.erasmus-entrepreneurs.eu/page.php?cid=5</ref> competent in business support, coordinated by a Support Office<ref>http://www.erasmus-entrepreneurs.eu/page.php?pid=016</ref> (currently run by [[EUROCHAMBRES]]).
By February 2017, more than 4,500 exchanges <ref>http://www.erasmus-entrepreneurs.eu/press/EYE_Programme_statistics_(January_2017)_58a61ff0b9417.pdf</ref> have been established and over 15,000 applications<ref>http://www.erasmus-entrepreneurs.eu/press/EYE_Programme_statistics_(January_2017)_58a61ff0b9417.pdf</ref> have been received
== Aim of the programme ==
Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs aims at fostering the entrepreneurial spirit and cross-border trade in Europe by facilitating exchange of knowledge, experience and networking between entrepreneurs intending to start a business or having just started one, and experienced entrepreneurs by working alongside each other. The programme also aims at guiding businesses on how to overcome market and business obstacles, so that they can make the most of the [[European Single Market]]. Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs in a nutshell:
* It offers new entrepreneurs the opportunity to learn from an experienced entrepreneur who is running a small or medium-sized enterprise (SME) in another participating country, * It enables the exchange of experience between new and experienced entrepreneurs, * It facilitates access to new markets and the search for potential business partners, * It enhances networking between entrepreneurs and between SMEs, * It allows experienced entrepreneurs to develop new commercial relations and find out more about opportunities in another EU country.
== History and development of Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs ==
In 2007, the European Parliament introduced a new budget line entitled "Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs”. The European Commission then started to design the Pilot Project with the aim of supporting mobility periods abroad for recently established and nascent entrepreneurs, with a view to improving their skills and fostering the cross-border transfer of knowledge and experience between entrepreneurs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ec.europa.eu/enterprise/entrepreneurship/support_measures/erasmus/feasability.htm |title=Enterprise and Industry - European Commission |publisher=Ec.europa.eu |date=2008-06-13 |accessdate=2013-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090508000301/http://ec.europa.eu/enterprise/entrepreneurship/support_measures/erasmus/feasability.htm |archivedate=2009-05-08 |df= }}</ref>
Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs comes under the [[Small Business Act for Europe]] which considers this initiative a key contribution “to create an environment within which entrepreneurs and family businesses can thrive and entrepreneurship is rewarded”. It currently falls under Programme for the Competitiveness of enterprises and SME's (COSME) 2014-2020.<ref>http://ec.europa.eu/growth/smes/cosme/index_en.htm</ref> <ref>https://ec.europa.eu/growth/smes/cosme/supporting-entrepreneurs_en</ref>
Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs is to a certain extent similar to the well-known [[Erasmus Programme]] for students as is a mobility action which addresses a particular target group. However, it is also clearly different: whereas the existing Erasmus programme in higher education enhances student-to-university relationships, the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs focuses on [[business-to-business]] relationships.
